data.title: Woodrow Wilson's Nobel Peace Prize medal.
data.meta_description: Nobel Peace Prize for 1919 presented to Woodrow Wilson in 1920, in recognition of his Fourteen Points peace program and his work in achieving inclusion of the Covenant of the League of Nations in the 1919 Treaty of Versailles. The face of the medal shows Alfred Nobel in profile, with inscription "ALFR NOBEL NAT MDCCCXXXVII OB MDCCCXCVI".  The reverse of the medal represents a group of three men forming a fraternal bond, with inscription "Pro pace et fraternitate gentium."   The edge of the medal is engraved with "Prix Nobel de la Paix XXXXXXX". Medal in hinged box, with gold embossing "XXXXXXX" on front. Accompanied by a framed presentation certificate in Norwegian, with inscription "Det Norske Stortings Nobelkomite har i Henhold til Reglerne i det af Alfred Nobel den 27de November 1895 oprettede Testamente tildelt Woodrow Wilson Nobel Fredspris for 1919. Kristiana den 10de december 1920", signed by members of the committee. Medal and certificate are also available as digital images on the Library of Congress Web site. Forms part of the Woodrow Wilson Collection at the Library of Congress, donated by Edith Bolling Galt Wilson.

Credit Line: Library of Congress, Rare Book and Special Collections Division

Availability of Reproductions

To inquire about copies of Rare Book and Special Collections Division items, contact the Photoduplication Service (telephone: 202-707-5640). Orders are accepted by mail and by fax.

The Photoduplication Service estimates that it takes 3-6 weeks to complete an order.
